newsitem.title: USA: Digital Q4 gross margins best in 3 years.
newsitem.headline: Digital Q4 gross margins best in 3 years.

text.p: Digital Equipment Corp said its gross margins improved in the fiscal fourth quarter to 34.6 percent of revenues, up from 32.6 percent a year earlier, and were its best in more than three years.
Fiscal third quarter gross margins were 33.4 percent, it said.
"This reflects continuing improvments in product cost, productivity programs and mix," Digital Chief Financial Officer Vincent Mullarkey said in a statement.
Digital reported fourth quarter earnings of $0.75 a share, surpassing the Wall Street consensus estimate of $0.73.
Revenues for the quarter declined to $3.5 billion from $3.7 billion a year earlier.
For the full year, Digital's revenues dropped to $13 billion from $14.6 billion in fiscal 1996.
Digital said product revenues for the fourth quarter were $2.0 billion, versus $2.1 billion a year ago. Product revenues were up nine percent from the third quarter, it said.
Service revenues were $1.5 billion, compared with $1.6 billion a year ago.
Product gross profit margins were 37.2 percent of revenues, compared with 34.3 percent a year ago.
Product profit margins in the third quarter were 35.3 percent.
Service gross margins were 31.1 percent of revenues in the fourth quarter, up one percentage point from a year ago. Service margins were 31 percent in the third quarter.

Digital said its personal computer business achieved a higher level of profit for the third straight quarter, continuing a significant turnaround from the third quarter of fiscal 1996, when it was hurt by significant price competition and high levels of inventory.
"The progress in our personal computer business has been excellent," said Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Robert Palmer.

Digital said the Windows NT segment grew about 50 percent from a year earlier, driven primarily by both Alpha and Intel servers. High-performance UNIX servers also experienced growth, and the company recorded strong growth in its storage business.
Digital said the quarter reflects its best inventory turns ever and the lowest accounts receivable days sales outstanding since the second quarter of fiscal 1995.

Digital said it ended the fourth quarter with $2.5 billion in cash. It said this represents an increase of $500 million over last year, while at the same time it repurchased four million shares of its common during the quarter.
Digital ended the quarter with about 54,900 employees, a reduction of 4,200 from the same period a year ago.
